paper_title.ja: The Importance of the Collision of Impinging Atoms in Thin-Film Growth on a Cryogenic Substrate
paper_title.en: The Importance of the Collision of Impinging Atoms in Thin-Film Growth on a Cryogenic Substrate

description.ja: Field-ion microscope observation of Mo deposition on a W tip at cryogenic temperature revealed that each Mo atoms, once adsorbed on a tip, was sometimes displaced to a certain distance, due to the collision of impinging atoms. This collision occasionally brought about the rearrangement of atoms in a cluster. The rearrangement of atoms induced by the collision is considered to play a very important role, particularly in epitaxial growth on a cryogenic substrate.
description.en: Field-ion microscope observation of Mo deposition on a W tip at cryogenic temperature revealed that each Mo atoms, once adsorbed on a tip, was sometimes displaced to a certain distance, due to the collision of impinging atoms. This collision occasionally brought about the rearrangement of atoms in a cluster. The rearrangement of atoms induced by the collision is considered to play a very important role, particularly in epitaxial growth on a cryogenic substrate.

publisher.ja: 公益社団法人 応用物理学会
publisher.en: The Japan Society of Applied Physics

paper_title.ja: Current-Voltage Characteristics of Field Electron Emission through Phthalocyanine Molecules on a Tungsten Field Emitter
paper_title.en: Current-Voltage Characteristics of Field Electron Emission through Phthalocyanine Molecules on a Tungsten Field Emitter

description.ja: The current-voltage characteristics on field emission through a four-leaf pattern, a two-leaf pattern and a single large bright spot of adsorbed Cu- and Co-phthalocyanines on a tungsten tip have been measured, and Fowler-Nordheim (FN) plots of field emission were obtained. The slopes of the FN plots for the four-leaf patterns were almost equal to or even a little higher than those for the substrate surface. In contrast, the slopes of the two-leaf patterns were about 10–15% lower than those of the substrate surface and the slopes of the single bright spots were about 20–25% lower.
description.en: The current-voltage characteristics on field emission through a four-leaf pattern, a two-leaf pattern and a single large bright spot of adsorbed Cu- and Co-phthalocyanines on a tungsten tip have been measured, and Fowler-Nordheim (FN) plots of field emission were obtained. The slopes of the FN plots for the four-leaf patterns were almost equal to or even a little higher than those for the substrate surface. In contrast, the slopes of the two-leaf patterns were about 10–15% lower than those of the substrate surface and the slopes of the single bright spots were about 20–25% lower.

paper_title.ja: Field Ion Microscope Observation of Mo Deposition with a Video System
paper_title.en: Field Ion Microscope Observation of Mo Deposition with a Video System

description.ja: A sequential field ion microscope (FIM) observation of the progress of Mo deposition on a tungsten substrate at 55 K has been made, with the aid of a video system. Some of the image spots of deposited adatoms which appeared on the W(110) plane were found to disappear during further deposition, which suggests that an adatom is expelled from its adsorption site by an impinging atom, and acquires a mobility on the substrate surface even at cryogenic temperatures.
description.en: A sequential field ion microscope (FIM) observation of the progress of Mo deposition on a tungsten substrate at 55 K has been made, with the aid of a video system. Some of the image spots of deposited adatoms which appeared on the W(110) plane were found to disappear during further deposition, which suggests that an adatom is expelled from its adsorption site by an impinging atom, and acquires a mobility on the substrate surface even at cryogenic temperatures.

publisher.ja: 社団法人応用物理学会
publisher.en: The Japan Society of Applied Physics

paper_title.en: A field ion microscope study on vapor deposition of copper on tungsten

description.en: Field ion microscopy observation was carried out on a copper thin film that was vapor deposited at a right angle to the tip axis onto one half of a tungsten tip cap. When copper was vapor deposited onto a tip kept at around 55 K, the deposit, which was made up of many fine crystallites and of a few larger crystallites at the interface with the substrate on each of the W{110} planes, was observed only on one half of the tip cap facing the evaporator. In addition, a well-ordered copper monolayer was observed on an area slightly wider than one half of the tip cap. By heating this deposit to 200, 300, or 400 K, recrystallization took place from the interface between the copper deposit and the substrate tungsten, and the thick copper area was reduced backwards to the direction of the evaporator. The recrystallization took place preferentially on some low index planes of tungsten. When copper was vapor deposited onto a tip kept at high temperatures (200, 300 or 400 K), copper crystals nucleated preferentially on W{110} planes and the condensed copper area spread to the shadow side by the forward migration of copper under the influence of impinging of depositing atoms. © 1995.

publication_name.en: Bulletin of the Japan Institute of Metals

paper_title.en: VAPOR-DEPOSITION OF CHROMIUM ON A TUNGSTEN TIP

description.en: Chromium was vapor-deposited onto one half of a tungsten tip from the direction normal to the tip axis in situ in a field-ion microscope and the fine structures of the deposit were observed in atomic scale. The areas of the deposited chromium varied depending on the preparation condition, i.e., deposition onto a low temperature tip (35 K), heat-treatment at a high temperature of the chromium which had been deposited onto a tip at 35 K, or deposition onto a high temperature tip. The results were a little different from those of the similar study of iron deposition previously reported by the authors.

paper_title.en: A FIELD-ION MICROSCOPE STUDY OF THE SURFACE CHEMICAL-REACTION OF TUNGSTEN WITH NORMAL-OCTANOL UNDER AN APPLIED POSITIVE VOLTAGE

description.en: The surface chemical reaction of tungsten with n-octanol diluted with inert n-octane under an applied positive voltage of 10 V with a rise time of 10 ns and a duration of several seconds was studied with the field ion microscope. The reaction was found to start in the region between the {231} and {351} poles where the densities of protruding kink site atoms are low and was found to proceed in a direction approximately parallel to the most densely packed atomic row and was found to extend corroded areas toward the central (110) pole. The relation between the size of n-octanol and the separation between the protruding kink site atoms in the region where the reaction starts is discussed.
